newsitem.title: USA: Retail gasoline continues to fall in N. California.
newsitem.headline: Retail gasoline continues to fall in N. California.

text.p: Against the national trend, gasoline prices at the pump in northern California continue to fall from springtime highs, according to a price survey conducted by the state's motorist association.
California State Automobile Association (CSAA) reported the average cost of self-serve unleaded gasoline has fallen two cents since last month to $1.47 a gallon.
Some cities, like San Francisco, saw average declines of nine cents to $1.45 a gallon. Prices at state capital Sacramento dipped three cents to $1.45.
Prices have gradually fallen from late April, when a rash of refinery shutdowns helped jack up self-serve unleaded to $1.54 a gallon, an 11-cent rise in one week.
"Northern California was really high with all the refinery problems. It had a long way to go (down)," one gasoline broker said.
The national average for self-serve unleaded fuel is up two cents from last month to $1.25 and eight cents higher than September, 1995.
Prices have eased with a seasonal decline in motorist demand following the U.S. Labor Day weekend.
Meanwhile, ample inventories and reports of higher European imports have forced down the value of NYMEX gasoline futures, which help determine the value of retail prices.
Unleaded gasoline for October delivery fell a sharp 1.74 cents Thursday to 61.32 cents a gallon.
But dealers in the California gasoline market doubted the price declines would continue, with regional stocks low at 26.9 million barrels and scheduled maintenance starting up at refineries.
"I doubt it will go much lower," a California broker said.
